author: By Steven Paulikas
title: My Parishioner Was Not Sentenced to Death. He Still Died.
description: What happens to the nearly two million people in our nation’s prison system demonstrates who we are as a people.
content: Witnessing unwarranted suffering is a solemn duty of the priesthood. But when one of my parishioners died of Covid-19 in a New York State prison, I felt the need to not only witness but to also tell the story he no longer can — the story of a prison system that failed to protect his life and the lives of so many others in its care, subjecting them to confusion, fear and even death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Major shifts in Israeli politics.
content: Israel is moving toward a government coalition deal that could sideline Benjamin Netanyahu, the country’s longest-serving prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russell Goldman
title: From One Child to Three: How China’s Family Planning Policies Have Evolved
description: For decades, couples were generally limited to one child to slow population growth. With a potential demographic crisis looming, the government now wants them to have more.
content: China on Monday increased the number of children married couples are legally permitted to have, to three from two, in an effort to stave off a looming crisis as the birthrate in the world’s most populous country steadily falls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Key Question in Mayoral Race: Who Will Get Latino New Yorkers’ Votes?
description: Hispanic voters, who may account for a fifth of  turnout, are considered to be up for grabs.
content: Eric Adams was not Representative Adriano Espaillat’s original choice to become New York City’s next mayor, but now that he had landed the coveted endorsement, Mr. Adams was in a forgiving mood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Raimund Hoghe, Choreographer of Strength and Frailty, Dies at 72
description: Born with a spinal deformity, he doubted he could ever dance, but he was able to incorporate his physical handicaps into his performances.
content: Raimund Hoghe, the German performer and choreographer who worked as a dramaturge for the choreographer Pina Bausch before creating dance-theater pieces that made as their subject his own body’s limitations, died on May 14 at his home in Düsseldorf. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Rays Don’t Look Like Contenders, but They Play Like Stars
description: Tampa Bay’s unassuming roster continues to confound. After beating the Yankees on Monday, they have won 16 of 17 games.
content: If there were a way to quantify what makes a team interesting, the Tampa Bay Rays would find it. Maybe they already have. They play as if trapped in a fun house mirror, wacky and warped and wondrously weird — and always bigger than they appear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Flávia Milhorance
title: As Virus Toll Grows, Brazil’s Political Divisions Spill Onto the Streets
description: Opponents of President Jair Bolsonaro have mounted the largest protests since the beginning of the pandemic, suggesting new volatility before next year’s elections.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — For weeks, President Jair Bolsonaro’s supporters have made their presence felt with the roar of motorcycles during boisterous rallies meant to show steadfast fealty to an increasingly unpopular leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Lines Never Felt So Good: Crowds Herald New York’s Reopening
description: Museums broke attendance records, movie theaters sold out and jazz fans packed clubs on a Memorial Day weekend that felt far removed from the prior year’s pandemic traumas.
content: The line outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art trailed out the door, down the rain-swept stairs, around the trees and past the fountain and the hot-dog stands on Fifth Avenue as visitors waited under dripping umbrellas. They were among more than 10,000 people who had the same idea for how to fill a rainy Sunday in New York City, turning the holiday weekend into the museum’s busiest since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Around the world, dogs are being trained to sniff out the coronavirus.
description: At Chulalongkorn University in Thailand, Labradors are being trained to sniff out Covid-19 in humans, as part of a global corps of dogs to be used to detect the virus. Preliminary studies, conducted in several countries, suggest that their detection rate may surpass that of the rapid antigen testing often used in airports and other public places.
content: At Chulalongkorn University in Thailand, Labradors are being trained to sniff out Covid-19 in humans, as part of a global corps of dogs to be used to detect the virus. Preliminary studies, conducted in several countries, suggest that their detection rate may surpass that of the rapid antigen testing often used in airports and other public places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Viet Thanh Nguyen
title: The Beautiful, Flawed Fiction of ‘Asian American’
description: Against the racist and sexist fiction of the “Oriental,” we built the anti-racist, anti-sexist fiction of the Asian American.
content: One is not born an Asian American. It’s an identity that is inherently political, and must be chosen. Before college, I had never even heard of the term, but I vividly remember the moment that I became Asian American.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: A Shocking Exit and a Sad Day for Tennis
description: Naomi Osaka, a superstar in the sport, pulled out of the French Open after she was fined for skipping a news conference. Did it have to end this way?
content: PARIS — Naomi Osaka’s withdrawal from the French Open was not the outcome anyone in tennis desired, and yet it happened just the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Chris Paul Won’t Be Kept Off the Court
description: His coach had been inclined to sideline him as he deals with a shoulder injury. But he talked his way into the lineup and helped Phoenix tie its series with the Lakers.
content: LOS ANGELES — A little over a week ago, Chris Paul christened the Phoenix Suns’ first trip to the postseason since the 2009-10 season with a bit of style. Paul, who is 6 feet tall, does not dunk often, but he rose to the occasion during warm-ups for the opening game of the Suns’ first-round series with the Lakers, leaping for an alley-oop as his teammates — and thousands of fans in Phoenix — celebrated in unison. It felt like a party. The city brimmed with hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: With a Chinese American Gunslinger, He’s Challenging the Whiteness of Westerns
description: Tom Lin is making his debut with “The Thousand Crimes of Ming Tsu,” a novel that has drawn comparisons to Cormac McCarthy and “True Grit.”
content: Ming Tsu, the bloodthirsty outlaw in Tom Lin’s surreal new Western, has a lethal superpower: His victims, blinded by their own bias, don’t realize he’s a threat until it’s too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: For 40 Years, He Climbed Ev’ry Mountain for Rodgers & Hammerstein
description: Ted Chapin steps down as the head of the organization that makes sure you revisit “Oklahoma!” and keep hearing “The Sound of Music.”
content: In 1981, two years after the death of Richard Rodgers and 21 years after the death of Oscar Hammerstein II, Ted Chapin got a call from Rodgers’s daughter Mary, asking if he’d like to run the Rodgers & Hammerstein office.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Short Life of a Syrian Girl, Chained and Hungry
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 31, 2021.
content: “We asked him more than once to unchain her, not to put her in a cage, but he constantly refused.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Edward St. Aubyn Wraps Serious Thoughts About Science in an Entertaining Package
description: St. Aubyn’s new novel, “Double Blind,” tells two love stories against the backdrop of brain-mapping, biochemistry, botany and the ethics of placebos.
content: By the time Edward St. Aubyn completed the last of his Patrick Melrose novels in 2012, it was clear that a new animal had approached the watering hole of fiction in England. This animal was of a species thought to have largely gone extinct: the anatomist of the remote upper classes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: On the Covid Front Lines, When Not Getting Belly Rubs
description: In Thailand and around the world, dogs are being trained to sniff out the coronavirus in people. So far, the results have been impressive.
content: BANGKOK — Bobby was a good boy. So was Bravo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: Kennedy Center Honors and Remembering the Tulsa Massacre
description: The Kennedy Center recognizes Dick Van Dyke, Debbie Allen, Joan Baez, Garth Brooks and Midori. And several networks air programs recognizing the centennial of the 1921 Tulsa massacre.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 31-June 6. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: How a Police Chief in Wyoming’s Ranchlands Lost Her War on Drugs
description: A campaign over meth, money and accountability cost law enforcement officers in Guernsey, Wyo., their jobs. Now their lawsuits are prying open the town’s secrets.
content: GUERNSEY, Wyo. — It was a few days before New Year’s Eve 2019, and Terri VanDam, the chief of Guernsey, Wyo.’s three-person Police Department, had run out of options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Why One American Basketball Team Won’t Be at the Summer Olympics
description: The U.S. invented basketball but does not dominate one form, three-on-three, when it comes to Olympics qualifying. So, go … Latvia?
content: When three-on-three basketball has its Olympics debut in Tokyo this summer, Latvia will be there. So will Poland. But a men’s team from the United States, birthplace of basketball and winner of 15 of 19 men’s gold medals in the traditional five-on-five game, will not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Media Groupthink and the Lab-Leak Theory
description: Sometimes the most destructive enemies of science are those who claim to speak in its name.
content: If it turns out that the Covid pandemic was caused by a leak from a lab in Wuhan, China, it will rank among the greatest scientific scandals in history: dangerous research, possibly involving ethically dubious techniques that make viruses more dangerous, carried out in a poorly safeguarded facility, thuggishly covered up by a regime more interested in propaganda than human life, catastrophic for the entire world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: The coronavirus variant discovered in India has a new name: Delta.
description: The W.H.O. said it will label variants with Greek letters instead of numbers. Scientists hope the change will end the practice of referring to the mutations by the places they were detected.
content: If you haven’t yet mastered the name of the latest coronavirus variant to set nations on edge — B.1.617.2, as evolutionary biologists call it — then fear not: The World Health Organization has proposed a solution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: China Says It Will Allow Couples to Have 3 Children, Up From 2
description: The move is the Communist Party’s latest attempt to reverse declining birthrates and avert a population crisis, but experts say it is woefully inadequate.
content: China said on Monday that it would allow all married couples to have three children, ending a two-child policy that has failed to raise the country’s declining birthrates and avert a demographic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Clinics Close, but Abortion Continues
description: Even as abortion is restricted, telemedicine allows some women to end unwanted pregnancies using legal medications.
content: Abortion is once again a prominent source of controversy, restrictive legislation and, for many, great distress. A little background may help put this in perspective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Jazmine Hughes and Katie Glueck
title: Garcia Rises, and Yang Changes His Tune: 5 Takeaways From Mayor’s Race
description: A new survey put Kathryn Garcia in the lead, shaking up the mayoral race with just weeks to go before Primary Day.
content: As the mayoral campaign of Dianne Morales, a progressive champion, continues to disintegrate around her, a moderate has ascended in the polls. Kathryn Garcia, the former sanitation commissioner, continued to gain momentum, and even some negative attention from a rival who once lavished praise on her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: O.E.C.D. Raises Global Growth Forecast Sharply, Citing Vaccines
description: The world economy is expected to expand by 5.8 percent this year, but success depends on beating down variants of the virus, the group said.
content: The global economy is expected to recover from the coronavirus pandemic faster than expected this year, as vaccinations in advanced economies and an enormous fiscal stimulus package in the United States unleash pent-up business activity and job creation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Kate Winslet Has No Filter
description: The star of ‘Mare of Easttown’ is back on the sides of buses. Without airbrushing.
content: Philly’s a tough town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘We’re Free Because They Were Brave’
description: Memorial Day had a special significance a year after many ceremonies honoring the nation’s fallen were canceled because of the pandemic.
content: A day set aside to honor the sacrifices of the nation’s veterans, Memorial Day 2021 was especially poignant a year after many memorial ceremonies — and many family trips and barbecues — were curtailed because of the coronavirus pandemic. Parades that had been canceled in 2020 were back in 2021. Services held online last year resumed in person this year. Holiday traffic returned, as did beach outings — at least in parts of the country not cursed with cold, rainy weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: As Harvard Case Looms at Supreme Court, Study Tests Value of Diversity
description: After prestigious law reviews adopted diversity policies for choosing student editors, researchers found, the articles they published were cited more often.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court is set to consider next week whether to hear a challenge to Harvard’s race-conscious admissions program. If the justices take the case — a reasonably safe bet — affirmative action in higher education, which has survived several close calls at the court, will again be in peril.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Couples in China can have three children now.
content: China said on Monday that it would allow all married couples to have three children, ending a two-child policy and moving to avert a demographic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Can a New ‘Change Government’ Change Israel?
description: The main players in the latest twist in Israeli politics have very different agendas, but one common goal: unseating Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
content: JERUSALEM — Naftali Bennett, who leads a small right-wing party, and Yair Lapid, the centrist leader of the Israeli opposition, have joined forces to try to form a diverse coalition that would unseat Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Celtics Fan Arrested After Kyrie Irving Is Nearly Hit by Bottle
description: Irving, who was walking into an arena tunnel when he was almost hit, had recently asked fans not to be belligerent or racist when the Nets traveled to Boston.
content: A fan in a Boston Celtics jersey was arrested Sunday after a bottle nearly struck Nets guard Kyrie Irving in the head following Boston’s Game 4 loss at TD Garden. It was the latest in a string of unruly fan behavior as N.B.A. arenas begin opening to near full capacity for the playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Gardiner
title: A New Era Dawns for Harley-Davidson
description: The feature-stuffed Pan America is a stark diversion for a company long associated with bulky, expensive cruisers. Early impressions suggest a potential blockbuster.
content: Recent years have not been kind to Harley-Davidson. Its sales have sagged, its core customers have aged, and its push toward the electric future, while newly serious, has underwhelmed so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘chekhovOS /an experimental game/’ Review: Life on a Merry-Go-Round
description: This ingenious interactive show finds the Russian playwright’s characters plotting against their creator.
content: What if fictional characters were stuck in an infernal, hopeless time loop, a cross between “No Exit” and being on hold with Delta Air Lines? You can imagine that the siblings in “Three Sisters” would like the opportunity to stop talking about going to Moscow and finally — finally! — do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Hughes
title: Two New Laws Restrict Police Use of DNA Search Method
description: Maryland and Montana have passed the nation’s first laws limiting forensic genealogy, the method that found the Golden State Killer.
content: New laws in Maryland and Montana are the first in the nation to restrict law enforcement’s use of genetic genealogy, the DNA matching technique that in 2018 identified the Golden State Killer, in an effort to ensure the genetic privacy of the accused and their relatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ​North Korea Accuses U.S. of ‘Shameful Double-Dealing’ on Missile Policy
description: In its first reaction to President Biden’s summit with President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, North Korean state media warned of an arms race.
content: SEOUL — North Korea’s state media on Monday criticized the United States for lifting restrictions on South Korea’s ability to build more powerful ballistic missiles in its first response to the summit between President Biden and Moon Jae-in, the leader of South Korea, earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Seminary Built on Slavery and Jim Crow Labor Has Begun Paying Reparations
description: The Virginia Theological Seminary is giving cash to descendants of Black Americans who were forced to work there. The program is among the first of its kind.
content: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Aims to Rebuild and Expand Legal Immigration
description: Documents obtained by The New York Times show far-reaching efforts by President Biden to remake the immigration system and undo much of his predecessor’s legacy.
content: WASHINGTON — If President Biden gets his way, it will soon be far easier to immigrate to the United States. There will be shorter, simpler forms and applicants will have to jump through fewer security hoops. Foreigners will have better opportunities to join their families and more chances to secure work visas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Ask Co-Workers if They’ve Had the Covid Vaccine?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on why asking about vaccine status isn’t a question of etiquette but of public health.
content: My employer, a large university, recently instructed us in an email titled “Vaccine Etiquette” not to ask fellow employees if they are vaccinated. I feel I have an interest in knowing this information for two reasons: First, the C.D.C. offers different guidelines for the vaccinated and unvaccinated. So I need this information to know which guidelines to follow. Second, if we are engaging in behavior that creates risk (e.g., breathing in an enclosed space), I have an interest in knowing what the risks are, in the same way that before having sex with someone I have a cognizable interest in knowing their S.T.D. status. Most people would not consider asking a person their S.T.D. status rude when both parties are engaging in potentially risky behavior. Why is this different?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 French Open: What to Watch on Tuesday
description: Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Ashleigh Barty start their French Open campaigns on the final day of first-round matches.
content: How to watch: 5 a.m. to 6 p.m. Eastern time on the Tennis Channel; streaming on the Tennis Channel+ app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: For China’s Single Mothers, a Road to Recognition Paved With False Starts
description: Unmarried mothers are often denied government benefits. A debate over the policy is being propelled by a declining birthrate and a new generation of independent Chinese women.
content: For a few glorious weeks, Zou Xiaoqi, a single mother in Shanghai, felt accepted by her government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Turkey Claims to Have ‘Captured’ Cleric’s Relative in Kenya
description: The removal of a Turkish citizen from his home in Kenya is part of the crackdown by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on those he sees as connected to a failed 2016 coup.
content: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s intelligence service claims it has “captured” a Turkish citizen related to a cleric they say orchestrated a failed coup, and taken him from his home in Kenya to Turkey, the state-run Anadolu news agency reported Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: For Sleep Apnea, a Mouth Guard May be a Good Alternative to CPAP
description: People with sleep apnea who can’t tolerate the noise and discomfort of a CPAP machine might benefit from a mouth guard or surgery.
content: Many people wear a CPAP machine at night to treat the interrupted breathing of obstructive sleep apnea, a condition that affects an estimated 22 million Americans. But CPAP machines can be noisy, cumbersome and uncomfortable, and many people stop using the devices altogether, which can have dire long-term consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel on Edge as Politicians Wrangle Over Coalition to Oust Netanyahu
description: Opposition politicians spent Monday locked in last-minute negotiations to form a bloc to force out Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving leader.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel’s political class was locked in frenzied horse trading on Monday, as opposition politicians struggled to strike a coalition deal to oust Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who in turn was waging a last-ditch effort to cling to power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Alfonso Tortolani
title: Why the Pandemic Was a Breakout Moment for the Cannabis Industry
description: For many Americans, having enough marijuana was as essential as stocking up on toilet paper. And suppliers found a way to get it to them.
content: This article is part of Owning the Future, a series on how small businesses across the country have been affected by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: More Than a Third of Heat Deaths Are Tied to Climate Change, Study Says
description: Sweeping new research found that heat-related deaths in warm seasons were boosted by climate change by an average of 37 percent.
content: More than a third of heat-related deaths in many parts of the world can be attributed to the extra warming associated with climate change, according to a new study that makes a case for taking strong action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to protect public health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Baseball Is Returning to the Olympics, With or Without the U.S.
description: Despite being ranked No. 2 in the world, Team U.S.A. has to fight its way to Tokyo in qualifiers that begin this week.
content: Baseball is known as America’s national pastime. The sport has long been a cultural touchstone in the United States, serving as a marker of seasons and influencing the national vocabulary. The largest professional baseball organization in the world, Major League Baseball, is based here. Many of the best players in the world hail from the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: To Motivate Workers, Republican Governors Experiment With Pain
description: Why does the federal government tolerate stingy state unemployment programs?
content: Only about 61 percent of the adults in Montana are employed at the moment. That leaves more than 300,000 who aren’t working. So I was surprised when the state’s Republican governor, Greg Gianforte, declared in May that Montana is experiencing a “labor shortage.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Alter
title: How Young G.O.P. Leaders Sold Out Their Generation
description: Elise Stefanik’s rise — and the fall of several young House colleagues — is an omen for a party struggling to reach a 21st-century electorate.
content: Once upon a time, a shiny new trio of young conservatives — Ryan Costello, Carlos Curbelo and Elise Stefanik — wanted to help build a modern, millennial Republican Party. The 30-somethings, all sworn into Congress in 2015, understood that millennials often agreed on many of the nation’s core problems, and believed it was up to them to offer conservative solutions. They were out to create a new G.O.P. for the 21st century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Britain Accelerates Relocation of Afghan Interpreters to U.K.
description: Britain will expedite the relocation of Afghan staff, largely interpreters, who worked for the country’s armed forces and are at increasing risk ahead of the withdrawal of U.S. and NATO troops.
content: LONDON — Britain will expedite the relocation of Afghan staff and their families who worked for the British government in Afghanistan, largely as interpreters, the Ministry of Defense said on Monday, acknowledging they had an obligation to protect local employees from Taliban threats as Western troops withdraw from the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Radical Modesty of Biden’s Budget
description: How to do big things without making bombastic claims.
content: Many reports about the Biden administration’s budget proposal, released Friday, convey the sense that it’s huge. President Biden, scream some of the headlines, wants to spend SIX TRILLION DOLLARS next year. (Sorry, can’t help doing my best Dr. Evil imitation.) It takes some digging to learn that the baseline — the amount the administration estimates we’d spend next fiscal year without new policies — is $5.7 trillion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Skateboarding’s Cardinal Rule: Dare to Be You
description: We asked photographers across the country to document how skateboarders come together to foster community.
content: They’re gathering in odd corners of the office park. They’re trolling under bridges. They’re jumping stairs and grinding rails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Fans
description: Because it’s getting hot out there.
content: When the temperature rises, it’s time to break out the floor, table and desk fans, especially if you don’t have central air-conditioning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Olivia Rodrigo’s ‘Sour’ Scores the Biggest Debut of the Year
description: The teen pop phenomenon’s first album opened with the equivalent of 295,000 sales in the United States, including the second-best streaming total of 2021 so far.
content: A year ago, the name Olivia Rodrigo barely registered in the music business. Back then, she was a teenage Disney actress who had moderate success contributing to the soundtrack of her show “High School Musical: The Musical: The Series.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: The Pandemic in the U.S. Has Vastly Improved. For These Families, the Worst Has Just Begun.
description: Families losing a loved one to the coronavirus now described a surreal, lonely kind of grief, as the threat from the pandemic lessens in the United States.
content: After more than a year of pandemic restrictions, many Americans are leaving their masks behind, making summer travel plans and joyously reuniting with family and friends. As more are vaccinated and new infections plummet, there is a sense that the worst of the pandemic is over in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 31, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 31, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Logan
title: I Wrote James Bond Movies. The Amazon-MGM Deal Gives Me Chills.
description: The character endures  because he is  protected by people who love him.
content: So, Amazon now owns 50 percent of 007.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: The Internet’s Favorite Catalog of Weird Places Rewrites History
description: Atlas Obscura has reviewed how it tells its stories about curious places in light of last year’s shift in how Americans view their past.
content: Samir S. Patel found us a parking spot on Madison Avenue and 103rd Street before it started raining last Wednesday, and led me under scaffolding into the grand lobby of the New York Academy of Medicine. There, a librarian, pleased to be giving her first tour in more than a year, took us down a long hallway into a room lined with rare books from the 16th and 17th centuries that she opened to show eerie anatomical renderings of humans without their skin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Yankees Are Swept in Detroit for First Time in 21 Years
description: Detroit outscored the Yankees by 15-5 in the three-game series. The Mets, meanwhile, had yet another game postponed.
content: DETROIT — Rookie Tarik Skubal pitched six shutout innings, and the Detroit Tigers beat the Yankees, 6-2, Sunday for their first home series sweep of New York in 21 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Naomi Osaka Quits the French Open After News Conference Dispute
description: The four-time Grand Slam tournament winner wrote on Instagram that she had suffered from bouts of depression since 2018 and that she would “take some time” away from the tennis court.
content: PARIS — The weeklong confrontation between Naomi Osaka, the second-ranked woman in tennis, and leaders of the sport’s four Grand Slam tournaments turned bitter on Monday when Ms. Osaka withdrew from the French Open, citing concerns for her mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Marvar
title: The New Detectorists
description: As an old outdoor hobby draws new followers, metal detectors are sweeping the country.
content: People have been metal detecting since 1881, when Alexander Graham Bell invented a device to find the bullet lodged in President James Garfield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall, Karan Deep Singh and Hari Kumar
title: Delhi Reopens a Crack Amid Uncertain Economic Prospects for India
description: The Indian capital lifted restrictions on manufacturing and construction, critical drivers of an economy that has been battered by the pandemic.
content: NEW DELHI — The Indian capital, which just weeks ago suffered the devastating force of the coronavirus, with tens of thousands of new infections daily and funeral pyres that burned day and night, is taking its first steps back toward normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Retired F.B.I. Agent Is Accused of Swindling Texas Woman Out of $800,000
description: The former agent told the woman she was on “secret probation” over drug crimes and at one point proposed marriage, federal prosecutors said.
content: A retired F.B.I. agent in Texas has been indicted on fraud charges and accused of conning a woman out of $800,000 by convincing her that she was on “secret probation” for drug crimes and needed to pay him and an accomplice for their work to “mentor” and “supervise” her, federal prosecutors said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Montgomery and Nick Corasaniti
title: After Dramatic Walkout, a New Fight Looms Over Voting Rights in Texas
description: After killing a Republican-sponsored bill to restrict voting in the state, Democrats vowed to oppose any efforts to revive it. Republicans pledged to pass it in a special legislative session.
content: AUSTIN — The battle among Texas lawmakers over a bill that would impose some of the strictest limits in the nation on voting access escalated Monday as Democrats and Republicans vowed that they would not back down over a highly charged issue that has galvanized both parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Recipes for Memorial Day
description: It’s a solemn day for many. Take a moment, before you cook, to honor its purpose and import.
content: Good morning. Here’s Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. on Memorial Day, from an 1884 address he gave in Keene, N.H., “in the full tide of spring, at the height of the symphony of flowers and love and life.” It’s worth recalling before anyone heads out into a yard or park today to grill with friends, a reminder of the purpose and import of the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The First of Nadal’s 100 French Open Victims Has His Say
description: And what he says, having played the Big Three in men’s tennis, is that it’s too hard to declare one the best. Now about that first match …
content: Lars Burgsmüller remembers telling himself he could beat Rafael Nadal on the red clay at the French Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez and Jennifer Jett
title: The Copa América soccer tournament will be played in Brazil instead of Argentina.
description: The games are scheduled to start in about two weeks in Brazil, where the rate of new cases is slowing but cases remain high.
content: The Copa América, South America’s largest soccer tournament, will be played in Brazil instead of Argentina, which is suffering its worst outbreak of the pandemic, organizers said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: Looking Beyond the Ayatollah to the Treasures of Iran
description: The organizers of a major London exhibition wanted to put politics aside and showcase the country’s rich 5,000-year-old culture. But politics kept getting in the way.
content: LONDON — The board game is roughly 4,500 years old. Shaped like a bird of prey, it has holes running down its wings and chest, where the pieces were once positioned. It’s one of a few dozen ancient objects that were set to travel from the National Museum of Iran for a spectacular exhibition at the Victoria & Albert Museum here. But they never came.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Seattle Storm Coach Dan Hughes Retires Midseason
description: Hughes, tied for the third most wins in league history, handed control to Noelle Quinn, who won a title with Seattle as a player.
content: SEATTLE — Seattle Storm Coach Dan Hughes abruptly announced his retirement on Sunday, six games into the season, saying the rigors of being a head coach in the W.N.B.A. has taken a toll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannibal B. Johnson
title: What I’ve Learned Teaching the Tulsa Race Massacre for Two Decades
description: The project of healing history’s wounds is difficult but necessary work.
content: About a decade ago, when third-, fourth- and fifth-grade students at Mayo Demonstration School in Tulsa, Okla., were studying the city’s history, their team of teachers gave them a special assignment: build a scale model of its once segregated Black business district, Greenwood, which was known as Black Wall Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Walls
title: Pools, From Above
description: On Memorial Day, just in time for summer’s unofficial start, allow yourself a moment of relaxation with these soothing aerial photos of cool, enticing waters.
content: A pool can be soothing long before you wade into its waters. Even viewed from a distance, pools can evoke a sense of stillness, a sense of calm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Texas Democrats Stymie G.O.P. Voting Bill, for Now
description: Republicans hit a significant stumbling block in their push to enact some of the strictest voting laws in the nation. But they could yet pass the measures through a special session of the Legislature.
content: Democrats in the Texas Legislature staged a dramatic, late-night walkout on Sunday night to force the failure of a sweeping Republican overhaul of state election laws. The move, which deprived the session of the minimum number of lawmakers required for a vote before a midnight deadline, was a stunning setback for state Republicans who had made a new voting law one of their top priorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: Peru says its true Covid death toll is almost triple its official count.
description: The country has struggled to contain the coronavirus since the pandemic began, and its official rate before the revised estimate was already the ninth highest in the world.
content: Peru says that its Covid-19 death toll is almost three times as high as it had officially counted until now, making it one of the hardest-hit nations relative to its population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: The Vogueing Protesters of Bogotá
description: “We were scared, but the people and the love from the public was our gasoline to go up there and confront the police,” said one.
content: For weeks, thousands of people have crowded the streets of Colombia, protesting inequality, rising poverty and police violence. President Iván Duque has deployed the country’s military and police forces, and more than 40 people have died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: How the ‘Wandering Meatloaf’ Got Its Rock-Hard Teeth
description: The dentition of the gumboot chiton, a lumbering mollusk, contains a rare mineral never before seen in a living animal.
content: The gumboot chiton is not a glamorous creature. The large, lumpy mollusk creeps along the waters of the Pacific coast, pulling its reddish-brown body up and down the shoreline. It is sometimes known, not unreasonably, as “the wandering meatloaf.” But the chiton’s unassuming body hides an array of tiny but formidable teeth. These teeth, which the creature uses to scrape algae from rocks, are among the hardest materials known to exist in a living organism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Lance Loud Was an Early Reality Star. He Was Also a Gay Punk Pioneer.
description: Loud was part of “An American Family” in 1973, but his wild band, Mumps, never signed a record deal. Now their songs are being released on the 20th anniversary of his death.
content: On February 20, 1973, Lance Loud earned a place in musical history that, at the time, nearly stopped his career cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Shaun Donovan Has the Résumé and the Money. He Just Needs the Votes.
description: In running for mayor of New York, Mr. Donovan is arguing that his leadership experience offers what the city needs in a time of crisis.
content: Five years ago, a powerful New York-based political strategist was rooting around for someone whom voters could envision as the city’s next mayor, someone with the right type of experience and gravitas to take on the weakened incumbent, Bill de Blasio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.6 Million Homes in California
description: A 1925 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, an 1890 Victorian in San Luis Obispo and a brand-new contemporary home in Cardiff-by-the-Sea.
content: Set along a winding street in the Hollywood Hills, just above the nightlife of the Sunset Strip, this property manages to be private and serene in a bustling area, with plenty of outdoor space and views of greenery from almost every room. The heart of Beverly Hills and the Cedars-Sinai medical complex are about 10 minutes away by car; the Miracle Mile business district and the backlots of Studio City are a 20-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Jim Huylebroek
title: A Siege, a Supply Run and a Descent Into a Decade-Old Battle
description: ‘Do you have body armor?’ the Afghan pilot asked us as we prepared for a trip to outposts surrounded by the Taliban.
content: MARJA, Afghanistan — The Afghan pilots discussed the approach into the small cluster of forward operating bases in Afghanistan’s south over tea and a lunch of rice pulao, much like surgeons discussing their next procedure. It would be quick, no more than 40 seconds on the ground, both helicopters landing at the same time, unloading the supplies before yanking up fast to get away from the easily targeted landing zones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Filipova and Henry Fountain
title: Here’s the Arctic Station That Keeps Satellites Connected
description: The world’s northernmost tracking base, on a Norwegian island, plays a crucial role in supporting research on climate change.
content: Arrayed across a plateau on an island in the high Norwegian Arctic, the 100 geodesic domes of the Svalbard Satellite Station look like abstract mushrooms sprouting from the snowy landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Ancient Rome Will Never Get Old. Take It From Mary Beard.
description: “What the Romans are teaching is always at that meta level of what it might be like to take a view different from your own.”
content: “What the Romans are teaching is always at that meta level of what it might be like to take a view different from your own.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $3.6 Million in California
description: A 1925 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, an 1890 Victorian in San Luis Obispo and a brand-new home in Encinitas.
content: A 1925 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, an 1890 Victorian in San Luis Obispo and a brand-new home in Encinitas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Thinking About Death, and End-of-Life Care
description: End-of-life discussions; a declining birthrate; ways to have a conversation.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
